On one hand, I think it is bad to accept misogynist cultural practices from other countries and that immigrants should be willing to integrate to Canadian society. I don't think it's in anyone's best interest to to make Canada similar to countries people are fleeing from.

On the other hand,  I suspect full face veiled women are among the most vulnerable  people in our society, as they might not speak the local language and are restrained from working. Denying them public services will make it worse for them. 

All considered, I think this law is a bad idea and we should instead work on alternative solutions that would enhance veiled women's integration to mainstream society.

From the latter perspective, looking at the Trudeau and Trump cabinet teams  and their financial track records and reputations and also at the way our lot is piling up massive, unending deficits, spending like drunken sailors and now warring with SB,  I cannot take the Canadian government seriously as sound macro-economic and public finances managers.

So I also find it difficult to have confidence in the Canadian equity market and prefer to invest south of the border where people with actual track records, reputations and expertise in these matters now serve in senior government roles.

Perhaps others feeling the same way has helped drag down the TSE.

I'm another such Canadian who is happy that the government is attempting to reduce partisanship in these appointments. It is impossible to find a group of adults who are completely without any political leanings, so there won't ever be such a thing as a group of completely neutral individuals. Those griping here about the risk of partisanship and bias on the CBC don't seem at all bothered, in the main, that the current board is heavily slanted toward Conservative membership. Comment: As a KIUC customer, I was disappointed that my PV installation would not qualify for NEM, but once I understood that there are costs involved in the transport infrastructure and that max PV power is not generated at a time when it is most needed and that watts are not "fungible" (a watt at noon isn't worth as much as a watt at midnight), it didn't take me long to "get over it".

KIUC has been forward thinking for the last 15 years (when I first became a customer).  They are one of the first utilities to take advantage of the Tesla/Solar City challenge to install battery backup.  Of course, KIUC has the advantage of being small enough that if the promised technology doesn't work out, Tesla will still survive.  

The single criticism I can level at KIUC is that they installed cell-based rather than fiber based smart meters preventing them from competing with Oceanic cable for internet options.   

Still, Dave Bissell is my hero, followed by Pat Gegen and the rest of the KIUC board.

Comment: Mr. Jenkins should read Jay Hammond's "Alaska Bush Rat" Biography, wherein Hammond states his purpose for creating the Fund. Few people get it. The fund is the people's protection against wasteful spending--not a rainy day cache. This idea that legislators have sole constitutional authority to spend the people's money needs a reality check. It's trumped by an even higher constitutional authority-- my  inherent right to live free of excessive debt and spending and to "enjoy of the rewards of my own industry." Yes, it's there in article I.  This right is indifferent to unions, to subsidies and to legislator's re-election schemes, or the advice of brilliant economists who think government's job is to stimulate the economy and to employ people. It's sensitive to one thing: every individual's right to live free of unsustainable debt and spending.

Paul's right about one thing: the people are ready for a fight. Cut spending and wean the next generation from a noose around their neck!

Comment: Without working out how MTHFR and other well-known metabolic markers "trigger" the expression of genes like these breast cancer genes, this research is meaningless.   There have been papers published on MTHFR and other markers for well over a decade.   There have been heat shock protein papers since the early 90s (at least).   

I'm pretty sure there are people who have already worked out the point I'm talking about.   What they haven't worked out is how to monetize it in a way that's more profitable than what already exists (e.g., drug treatments).   That's why it could "take a long time".

This science is not as new as some would have you believe.   China has been graduating people in genetic engineering (including PhDs) since the mid-90s.  I have reason to believe they've been applying in in China just as long.

Comment: When the eye came over land in the Naples area about 120 miles south of Tampa Irma started to fall apart. This is critical for any storm. They can't regenerate like they can over water and the frictional force disrupt circulation. Also as flat as Florida is just east of the Naples area is one of the highest parts of the state with rolling hills which break storms up.

I didn't ride it out - I stayed with a friend close by who was better protected by surrounding trees and buildings and 35 feet above sea level. If you are within a mile of water and less than 10 feet above sea level you are crazy to not leave. Its not cool or macho or whatever. Its a giant pain to be sitting in the dark hot, sweaty, no TV, etc. Its like how people have been swept away in the streams there in thigh deep water. You might make it wading across but its a certainty that if you don't try you won't die. For noobies to Florida every storm is a learning experience. We need to send them the right message.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Two other things to remember about the Juneau "access" road. 

1.  Real cost:  It's not a $574 million "access" road as both advocates and some opponents say. It's more like a $1 billion "access" road.

The $574 million hasn't been updated in a couple years. Each time it has been updated, the costs have gone up $100 million or more.  As a former DOT official famously and truthfully said,  "We won't know the real total cost until we issue a contract," or something to that effect. 

2.  Impact on other regions:  Whether it's a $1 billion "access" road or a mere $574 million "access" road, there will be severe impacts on other parts of Southeast Alaska as well as Anchorage, MatSu, Fairbanks and the rest of the state. 

Advocates of the "access" road like to say it's 90% federal money and only 10% state match. What they conveniently forget to say is that's $480 million (or more) and 10% match that won't be available for critically needed projects elsewhere in Alaska.

Comment: I do not object to taxes. Nor do I think there should be no tax increase this session. But to pursue the very tax that the voters soundly rejected just months ago is foolish. We are not closer to an overhaul of the revenue system if it won't pass the Legislature, which is what Sen. Courtney is saying, or if it would be defeated at the polls. There is ample room to reform the taxes we have in a way that does not put more burden on low and middle income people, who can ill-afford it since their real wages continue to fall. Tax reform is indeed needed, but in a fair and non-regressive way.

And it's a myth that the gross receipts tax would somehow magically be immune to business cycles. Just look at Washington state, with both a sales tax and gross receipts tax. Their leaders perennially complain about this very thing. Their solution: add an income tax!

Comment: Our current form of city government  --  strong council + city manager  --  is very clearly not working.  

If we have to shift to a Class Two city form of government to give us a separately-elected mayor who has veto power over Council actions, then we should do it.  

The current structure has backfired badly twice in the past ten years  --  the "Worst Council Ever" of 2006, and now this "Silly Council" that can't even carry out an incredibly mild first use of the ethics process it came up with.  That's two out of three councils dysfunctional  --  this is not working for us.

I don't know why we have such trouble electing a City Council that remembers it is representing the voters of this town.  But clearly, we do.  

So let's take whatever steps are necessary to re-create a standard American separation of powers in Port Angeles' government.  This unilateral form does not work here.  I'm starting to be very glad we have this coming up on the ballot next year.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: Actually there are 3 major differences between the infrastructure requirements of an EV and a ICE.
1) The majority of the time an electric will be charged at home overnight giving the driver a "full tank" every morning to start the day meaning they will only have to charge up on very long trips.
2) It is massively more expensive to build and maintain a gasoline service that to put in a public plug for those who need a charge while on long trips
3) Cost of electricity is constant ( no overnight price increases before a long weekend) and it's roughly 10% of the price of gasoline.

Comment: Although I disagree with some of the sentiments expressed in this piece by this fine writer, I do agree that Native Alaskans should hold on furiously to their culture, as should all peoples who live in places dominated by foreign culture, because if they don't, those foreign cultures will supplant their own. I am an American of Irish descent, and I appreciate the de-anglicization of place names in Ireland and the regrowth of the Irish language there. But, let's recognize that the domination of one culture over another is not unique to the Americas and not unique to the time of European dominance in world affairs. The Chinese dominated Vietnam for over a century, as they now dominate Tibet. Arabs, Berbers, and Turks dominated much of southern Europe for centuries. There are many, many more examples of the same. In fact, the view that only Europeans and their descendants engage in cultural domination is itself a result of ethnocentrism and its dehumanizing "noble savage" fantasy.

Comment: The EPA's allowable level of glyphosate residue on carrots is 5ppm, which is equivalent to 5mg/kg. One large carrot is about 80 grams or .08kg, so 5mg/kg(.08kg) = 0.4mg of allowable glyphosate residue on the carrot. If there are 200mg of caffeine in a cup of coffee, that's 500 times as much caffeine in the coffee as glyphosate on the carrot, and if caffeine is 29 times as toxic as glyphosate (rat oral LD50 192 vs 5600) then the acute toxicity of your morning cup of coffee is about 14,500 times as high as the carrot with glyphosate residue.  Significant digits are off in the calculation, I know.

The actions of Californians notwithstanding, a thousand things in your daily environment will kill you off long before Roundup will.

Comment: That we are dumping softwood lumber is, from my understanding of the issue, a complete misrepresentation.  They cannot meet their needs without our lumber, which costs more because our trees are bigger.  In other words, their pieces of lumber are smaller and therefore costs less.  Re standing up for ourselves, softwood fights have been going on for decades; that Canada has won every WTO case ought to say it all. 

As far as dairy, their own  farmers have said in no uncertain terms that Canada is NOT the problem. The problem is they were encouraged to expand their industry and now too much milk being produced (largely by corporate farms) to the point of dumping millions of gallons of it.  In Wisconsin there are ~1200 dairy farmers; in some cases one state has more farms than all of Canada.  We are 1/10th their population, how much milk do they think we can use if they cant absorb their production? I suspect the desire is to dump their overproduction here, as opposed to downsizing.

Comment: Before coming up with urban design solutions (land use and transportation), one needs to know the aggregate demand over the next 25 years. Unless one knows how much housing is needed, coming up with solutions is working blind. So, quantify the problem and the alternative solutions to the problem, for the entire lower mainland. This doesn't mean one does nothing while waiting, as it is possible to work on different parts of a problem at the same time. Many alternatives including a factory production model of dense structures (see Toyota's housing corp.), non-profit corporations,  leasing public land, etc. By the way, don't forget that a serious earthquake and quickly rising water levels might lower demand.

Comment: Anyone that believes turning it over to the private sector means lower costs should be treated for brain disorders. Have you ever seen the cost of maintaining highways in Alberta, BC, and Ontario.

Ontario began privatizing highway maintenance in 1996. In 1999 the Ontario auditor general found private road maintenance was costing $2 million more than when it was a not-for-profit service.

British Columbia privatized highway maintenance in 1988. A study carried out for the province in 1994 found that costs actually increased by $19 million per year in 1992-93 constant dollars

In Alberta no study was undertaken because no one, including the province’s auditor general, has the mandate or the access to examine the consequences of privatization. 

It's a cash cow for a few owner friends of the provincial government and a cash drain to employees. And always initiated by Conservatives looking out fro a few of their friends that donate big.

Comment: Let's talk about the "IRS operation" - because facts do matter.  Section 501 (c) (4) of the IRS code exempts certain types of non-profit organizations from federal income taxes.  The statute requires civic organizations to be "operated exclusively for the promotion of social welfare".  The IRS has traditionally used a more lenient interpretation of the statute that such organizations be involved "primarily" (rather than exclusively) in social welfare - which has allowed "social welfare" organizations to engage in lobbying and campaign activities "as long as those activities are not their primary activity."  In the wake of the formation of the Tea Party, a raft of "social welfare" organizations sought tax free status which appeared to actually be political organizations - not social welfare.  The IRS investigated these organizations to insure that they were, in fact, "primarily" involved in social welfare. - in other words, they were doing their jobs.

Comment: Ronin, I understand your point.  I teach reading comp to honors students, and always remind them to not let their biases lead them to see things that aren't there.  I see it's possible to interpret "...what was happening with REGARD to the Civil War..." to mean things happening in Jackson's time which eventually built up to the Civil War, especially if said by someone who's not precise about his choice of words.  Trump may be a "concept" person who means what he said about Jackson being angry at the dumb goings-on, and wasn't focusing on the exact years things happened.

But I hope you also recognize that most people who care about both informing and being understood would say something like, "Jackson was angry with the unreasonable things going on IN HIS TIME that eventually led to the Civil War."  If you don't say it the "common" way, you leave yourself open to the grammar police, political opponents, and those who really believe you're uneducated.

Comment: The annual yield from America's growing stock of forests cannot sustain its growing demand for lumber products.  Whether from public lands or its vast private forest land holdings, the Annual Allowable Cut (AAC) of the USA's softwood growing stock is not sufficient to feed its domestic requirements.  Fully 1/3 of US wood products (lumber, moulding, door frames, forms, plywood, strand board etc) comes from Canada.  Further,  US private forest land owners can, in general, export raw logs without restriction.  This they do in vast amounts, particularly to Asia.

Over time the ~20% tariff will cause  the price of lumber (per thousand board ft) to rise even faster than it has been.  A year ago it was $250, today it's $385.  So, even though a tariff will be imposed, the price for the product will go up, in both Canada and the USA.

Comment: Organic aquaponics was first used in 4330 BC in China and the Aztecs used it as early as 1150 CE.  The truth is that large organic soil farms are lobbying for this change as they see a threat to their profits from aquaponics.  In a time of climate change and in a country with where the average meal has 1500 food miles, more aquaponics is badly needed.  Aquaponics can more easily be done in a controlled environment and uses only about 5% of the water that soil agriculture does.

There is an argument that some hydroponic growers are growing in GMO sludge.  Yes that needs to change.  And so do the organic soil farms that use conventional chicken manure from birds that are fed GMOs.  Organic soil farms are commonly using plastic "mulches" and irrigation which leach PCBs and other contaminants into their soil.  The rules do need to be changed but organic aquaponics should continue to be granted organic certification.

Comment: The dividend splitting (sprinkling is too Trumpy) proposals are simple in theory. In pracuce, the problem is that the term "reasonable" cannot be legislated, so a CRA auditor with a checklist will be sitting in boardrooms telling taxpayers what is.  Since evety fact situation is different, this will not end well.  If these proposals are implemented, look for Appeals and the courts to be clogged for years and an army of CRA hires big enough to eat up whatever revenue Mr Morneau thinks they will pull in.

There are so many time bombs in the capital gains/dividend arbitrage rules that it is hard to know where to start.  As one example of a depressingly long list, the proposals would make proceeds from life insurance policies taxable notwithstanding that the premiums were never deductible.  Many estates which have insured their death tax liabilities will now have roughly half of what they had planned and will have to liquidate assets.

The passive income proposals are, simply, unworkable.

Comment: Building homes on traditional flood plains should be discouraged.  If you do build homes on a flood plain some common sense should be considered. 
Make plans to elevate your main living spaces higher than normal.  Basements should have adequate sump pump drainage landscaping with higher elevations than the surrounding roadways etc.  Don't spend money renovating basements knowing that someday they can be flooded.  This can go a long way to help keep your home more habitable in a flood situation like we are seeing today. 
Many people would not be so distressed if they were more cognizant  and prepared and flood water was only in their basements and not flowing into their living rooms, kitchens and bedrooms.

I think even more important than the property was what Burke perceived to be his power and prerogatives as a bishop.
<His longern goal was to become head of the archdiocese of Chicago... Pope Francis prevented that from ever happening.>
I think Pope Benedict gets some credit for that. Chicago wasn't open when Benedict removed Burke from St. Louis, but by removing him to Rome, Benedict pretty much assured that Burke would not be a diocesan bishop again. The move to the Signatura was widely seen as an instance of the ancient Roman practice known as "Promoveatur ut amoveatur" (Let him be promoted in order to remove him.) Of course, Francis could appoint Burke to a diocese (he could have appointed him to Chicago in 2014), but I don't think he will. If Francis could find a bishop willing to have him, perhaps Francis will assign Burke as an auxiliary bishop. He would be the second cardinal so assigned.

Comment: Todd, thanks for weighing in.  We're all pretty sensitive to tax increases these days, to be sure.  However, to clarify your comment, the tax that was rejected was a bond to build a new high school.  The levy that ran at the same time in 2015 passed strongly, with almost 65% voter approval.  This levy is simply a renewal of that one, and is neither a new tax nor a 39% hike; mathematically it will cause little, if any, increase to what folks pay now.  It's not a new tax.  The levy funds are 22% of the district's budget, and this number is not being increased.  The levy pays for shop and vocational programs, athletics, counselors, smaller class sizes, much of our amazing music program, and a large portion of maintenance.  To lose it would be a major blow to our economy and our ability to recruit both new businesses and good teachers.  Our business and medical community are urgently asking the community to renew it.

Comment: Have you actually looked at Eugene's Zero Vision draft? It's pretty clear that the focus is to make it less likely that motorists will die at the hands of other motorists. This is because their "data", which is heavily biased towards injured motorists, indicates that the majority of roadway injuries and deaths in Eugene are motorist on motorist and that this type is increasing.

It's no big surprise that motorist-only traffic violence is increasing in Eugene. We have lost huge numbers of pedestrians, bus riders and cyclists back to their car seats over the past decade. Walking to work is down almost 30% from its peak, riding the bus is down over 50% and cycling is down over 40%. We're simply running out of soft targets and now have to settle for harder ones.

If implemented as drafted, Eugene's Zero Vision will contribute to our unprecedented loss of active transportation participation. It's another opportunity to live up to our fantastic potential squandered by the Jon Ruiz gang.

Comment: Oregon has an atypical dog bite statute that holds dog owners strictly liable for the payment of  "economic damages." Oregon Revised Statutes, section 31.360 subdivision (1) provides that "[f]or the purpose of establishing a claim for economic damages, as defined in ORS 31.710 (Noneconomic damages), in an action arising from an injury caused by a dog: (a) The plaintiff need not prove that the owner of the dog could foresee that the dog would cause the injury; and (b) The owner of the dog may not assert as a defense that the owner could not foresee that the dog would cause the injury."

There is always the possibility of using deadly physical force in defense of oneself or others if a reasonable person perceives your dog to be a threat.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: I'm not opposed to the road, but there are three things that need to be addressed. First, what do you say to the people living in other places prone to awful weather and accessible only by low-quality airstrips with others nearby, such as Russian Mission or Anaktuvik Pass? If you're justifying spending millions of public dollars on a road for King Cove, why not them?

Second, be honest about the use. It's not going to be just for evacuations, everyone knows that. It's going to let cannery traffic access the more cost-effective runway as well. 

Finally, who is going to maintain this road and how. DOT, presumably? Does DOT have sufficient equipment and personnel there or will this require additions? The road is, after all, critical for life and safety, right? It will require regular, year-round [and expensive] maintenance.

Comment: Professor Dershowitz is correct that Trump had the power to pardon Flynn and that he had the authority to end the investigation of Flynn at any time. However, he ignores a third issue.

Trump does not have the authority to order an investigation of Flynn (which he implicitly did by not ordering an end to the investigation when it was in his power to do so) and attempt to influence the results of that investigation. This would be like a police chief ordering detectives to investigate a crime but also ordering them not to identify the criminal as X.

The president's power to pardon and direct the justice department is ultimately held in check by the voting public and their decision to vote for or against the president in the future. The president has the power to end prosecution and criminal investigations. However, when he decides to do so he must use those powers so his actions are subject to democratic review. From a legal perspective, that is what Trump should have done.

Comment: The idea that I may be doing the same job as a man and get paid less for it is outrageous.  But these gender gap figures are not really talking about the same jobs - they're talking about overall pay differences between how much men earn versus women in the workforce.  So the man might be an engineer and the woman a cashier, yes their pay scales would be very different.  But they're doing different jobs, and I would expect them to be paid differently.  

Thus most of this gender gap analysis for me is pretty bogus.  I do believe that in some jobs where men and women are doing the same work, women are discriminated against and paid less. Those should be investigated.  But the sweeping denunciation here does nothing for women who really are being dinged in the workforce.  Another example of skewed truth in the media - even if you can't call it a 'false fact'.

Comment: Interesting article by Douglas Todd pertaining to immigrants increasingly giving up  PR status, and many instead deciding to live here on a 10 year renewable visitors visa.  

"Renunciations are growing in number and will likely remain high, says an internal report from Canada’s immigration office in Shanghai, China, the largest source country for immigrants to B.C."

Seems they are getting tired of being hassled to report income and adhere to all the conditions needed to maintain permanent residency.

Mind you Mom and the kids are still holding onto Canadian PR status/citizenship, but this way Dad can fly back and forth and keep income unreported and in his name. No questions asked. And they can always sponsor Dad at a later date.

Of course this is no news to ,many of us who have seen the 10 year visa being used for defacto residency, but the news is immigrants actually switching PR status to benefit from it.

Comment: Rubbish!

I've never really had a problem with Eagle Cab or the others in Fairbanks, except that it's as expensive as the hailing system is antiquated. And the peak hour and location problem (I've waited 45+ minutes for a taxi at both Fairbanks and Ted Stevens International Airports). Problems the taxi companies have had every power to address themselves but simply rely on regulation to avoid modernization.

I've never used Uber or Lyft but I have used Grab in South East Asia. "Grab Car" is like Uber in that a price is quoted up front, "Grab Taxi" is just a way to hail a cab with your smartphone, with the added benefit of a digital record of your transaction and an estimated up-front fare (you also pay for time waiting in traffic). What a world of difference. It's sad when the taxi-rides in developing countries are an order of magnitude better experience than in AK. Every Grab ride was more modern and clean than every taxi I've used in Alaska. 10 min wait to ride 300+ miles if you want

The mayor et al has been incompetent and negligent. Residents are fined and outed but politicians get off scott-free again.

Comment: Believe it or not, every reason to go ahead with the I-70 expansion has been countered with reasonable, data-driven arguments against it. There are a number of people who have thoughtfully addressed the myriad of issues surrounding this boondoggle. 

Visit the website, http://www.ditchtheditch.com, and you will find a TON of information, including CDOT's own report that states how moving the highway north would mean fewer residents would be impacted AND 270/76 are slated for expansion in addition to I-70 any way. 

While I am NOT a transportation "wonk," I was at a number of the public meetings that began 14 years ago. CDOT came in with a proverbial "chip on its shoulder" in regards to addressing community concerns. They had their plan and they were NOT going to deviate from it. The "ditch" idea came from the community, but only as a desperate last attempt to mitigate some of the pollution and environmental issues that the highway expansion would FURTHER impose on their neighborhoods.

Comment: Breez:

I'll agree with you on the timing of the presser, but I think the idea was to have it after the first practice.

There's a lot of talent that you list leaving the Bruins, but a lot of those deals can be explained a bit more rationally. The Wheeler deal cleared some cap space and got Rich Peverley, who played a useful role in the Cup run. Seguin and Kessel had both worn out their welcomes. Boychuk and Hamilton were victims of cap space issues, which would be the GM's fault. Lucic leaving was probably also an issue of affordability.

As for the list to get rid of, I'll agree on the spare-parts guys Hays and Belesky. Rask should not have been signed to as big a contract as he was. Backes has been good, if injured, so I wouldn't get rid of him, and Krejci is top-6. As for Chara, he is one of those players that you treasure when you have and simply cannot replace without cloning.

Comment: Here's the reality.   Any argument that these jets are needed for "National Defence" is just silly.   Our National Defence relies upon our proximity to the U.S. and our membership in NATO.    

If you truly want Canada to have independent National Defence capabilities then we'll have to sacrifice in other areas in a big way.   This is because Canada is a huge country with a small population (therefore, a small tax base from which to draw funds for all things government controlled).    Our needs are actually minimal - just enough to demonstrate a presence.

So the appropriate jet will be one that allows Canada to fulfill any future military obligations overseas (which in future may not require manned jets), while offering the ability to patrol in Canada and intervene (if necessary).   

We simply don't need and cannot afford the latest and greatest fighter/bomber.     Canada should buy what's already out there and what can serve our needs for the next 3 decades.

Comment: "Prisons see drop in solitary confinement use as vulnerable groups granted immunity."

Vulnerable groups, such as the mentally ill and pregnant women, are NOT granted immunity from solitary confinement.. All that's happened is that Corrections Canada now has a new "policy" in place. It's the same as any employer having a policy in place, but one which it isn't obligated to follow due to law or labor contract. That policy may be there later today, or it may not. The policy may be followed, or it may not. 

The Liberals could have easily included the policy's provisions in its recent legislative changes. The obvious reason why they didn't is because Corrections Canada intends to violate the policy, at least in some cases. So it's virtually assured that the mentally ill, pregnant women and other vulnerable inmates will still be sent to solitary confinement.

I applaud the BC Civil Liberties Association and the John Howard Society for continuing to challenge this inhumane practice.

Key - which refutes or paints a different picture than post-Exilic period as the only approach:
It's really hard to know when the story of the exodus first was put into written form. But it appears in one of the earliest poems in the Bible, the Song of the Sea, found in the middle of the book of Exodus [Exod 15:1-22]. This victory hymn probably dates to the 12th century B.C.E.
It's also important to note that the Exodus is a theme that's mentioned over and over again in various parts of the Bible.

Comment: A Republican dominated caucus controlled the process over the last decade,  yet it  is all Walker's fault for our fiscal mess and the Dividend being cut. as if these "helpless" legislators had nothing to do with it?  Are we to believe that those record appropriations of years past never happened?    

 Remember, only the Legislature has the power to appropriate funds. While the Governor creates the budget, the Legislature writes the check to cover it.  The governor can line item veto; however, he cannot add money back.  Importantly, those vetoes can be reversed by these same "helpless" legislators .  

If theses legislators  were serious about fiscal management they could have simply appropriated less money and the Governor could have done nothing about that.  All they can claim is they "funded" the budget; however, they funded it to significant degree with savings.   That is analogous to being proud that you paid off the Visa card using the balance from your retirement funds.

Comment: I've never trusted the "throw-it-together-and-take-it-apart" rides that are available at temporary carnivals. In the past I've tried a few carnival rides and they've always seemed shoddy, some quite rickety, and they are clearly not as sturdy as permanent rides at established amusement parks. That's not to say that one can't get injured on a ride at large popular amusement parks like Cedar Point or Disneyland or Six Flags but at least the odds appear to be less, and those rides - which are under a higher surveillance and maintenance cycle - don't have multiple people constantly monkeying with them to move them from place to place. They have established 24/7 crews constantly observing, computerized monitoring, they will temporarily halt or close a ride down regardless of how long a line is to investigate every little odd noise or anything a rider reports as unusual, and they have on-site maintenance shops constantly replacing worn parts and doing quality assurance on a set schedule.

Comment: Also in that spirit, I have a question for you:  Advice, if you will.  

This forum offers some interesting challenges, and apparently opportunities to censor opposing viewpoints.  I came into it thinking that I would be disinclined to approve anonymous viewpoints, or viewpoints given under false names (i happen to think we should all post under our own names), but seeing the many false handles, pseudonyms, etc., I found the choices difficult.  What I had settled on was to give a moderate response to anonymous comments, but approve of their civility as long as they didn't slander anyone, threaten, or use profanity that would make the conversation offensive to young people (like my daughter).

What do you think?  Should I follow my first instinct, and routinely disapprove anonymous comments, because they are anonymous?  I'm tempted to urge others to do so, however effective that may be..Or, acknowledging the validity of certain anonymous commentors, approve them with the offered caveat?

Comment: Depends on where you live.  The tax has been in place in BC for a few years now, and no change is expected until the national rate reaches $30 per tonne. So only if you live in Alberta will you see any new carbon tax next year, which is probably why the article didn't mention it.  In case you're wondering....at $30 per tonne it amounts to 6.67 cents per liter of gas.

Comment: Mr. Gambee:  You're quite right...we all share ownership of our public schools.  We share the successes and the failures.  Sometimes I think too few successes and too many failures.  I also agree that simply "throwing more money at it" is not the answer.  I also agree that, to a large degree, most people don't really know what "it" is.  We, indeed, need a national, non-partisan conversation regarding education in America.  We need to decide, at all levels of responsibility (national, state and local) just what it is we hope to achieve.....a basic question, so basic it seems simplistic....just what do we hope those twelve or thirteen years in public schools will do for kids?  How will the school experience improve their lives, now and in the future?  Will school make them "better" persons?  What are the schools' responsibilities vis a vis parents?  and a host of associated questions whose answers shold help define how we can better serve our kids.

Comment: One of the few things leaders of the two parties in control of American politics agree on is the "sanctity" of the two-party system.  Any systemic changes which would promote the viability of a third, fourth or whatever, party have little chance for adoption. 

 Ideas such as preferential voting which would allow alternative candidate support w/o the issue of "throwing away one's vote" have little chance of becoming law.  Usually third-party candidates are "farther out" on the political spectrum than the two major party candidates.  Consequently, voting for them often has the unintended consequence of benefiting the "major" candidate least like your choice.....think of Ross Perot and Ralph Nader.    Preferential voting would allow you to vote for your first choice and, if that candidate is not the "winner", to have your vote tallied, instead, to your second choice.  This would be a radical departure to the current system and give a huge boost to third parties ...therefore, won't happen

Comment: Cliff, I'm just a layman trying to understand the science, and happy to change my mind on anything as new evidence presents itself.  I have zero credentials, but then the problem with that argument is that there are scientists with impeccable credentials on both sides of the climate debate.  My point on weather models is simply that you have the opportunity to test predictions on a frequent basis.  I'd think that would help to improve those models over time.  

On uncertainty in the models, it would be interesting to see the magnitude of the potential error of other variables vs. the magnitude of the effect we're attributing to CO2.  Not sure if Patrick Frank is close or way off on that one.

The radiative effects of CO2 are actually growing logarithmically rather than exponentially, aren't they?  i.e., theoretically you get the same warming effect (~1.2 deg C) from a doubling of the concentration, whether that's from 300 to 600ppm or 600 to 1200ppm.

Comment: This issues seems muddled with different opinions and varying statistics.  I think what is difficult to assess is the bigger picture and real issue in my mind which is not just about the number of these these fish in the wild but the effect that a large decrease or extinction would have on the bigger ecosystem.  Ecosystems are often based on interdependence and interconnection.  So in the food chain, perhaps these fish have a job to eat and consume certain plants and animals to who's population will now not be controlled, which then has other effects. Perhaps these fish are the main food source for animals higher up on the food chain so now they will starve and their population will drop as a direct result which then has other effects on animals and plants that may connected to those animals.  So looking at counts of only the species being harvested is missing the bigger picture.  Perhaps with logical big picture thinking the actual effects on the ecosystem can be calculated better.

Comment: One would assume that in a legitimately objective legal system the courts (and especially a Supreme Court) must permit input from all relevant stakeholders. By deselecting LGBTQ intervenors in a case where LGBTQ rights and interests are fundamental to the matter at hand, the SCC's original position failed the test of objectivity. Imagine if the SCC were to hear and rule on an appeal application about a pipeline in northern Canada after deselecting intervenors representing aboriginal interests. It just wouldn't happen. And it shouldn't happen, just as it shouldn't in a case where LGBTQ interests as well as the legitimate right of LGBTQ citizens/residents to be protected from discrimination are at stake. This is not about special interests. It's about the right of people from a historically oppressed community to be able to protect themselves from discrimination. To shut them out of the process would have transformed the SCC into little more than a kangaroo court.

Comment: About 30 years ago decisions were made to move mental health patients from the hospital in Salem to "community based solutions." Cases were made for it, but there were very few community-based options and no money was allocated to create or give incentives to organizations to build and operate them. 
I was on a board of a mental health organization in another county at that time. Our organization operated a very small facility, but we knew we couldn't handle the extras who would come to our community. Nevertheless, patients were released with no good options in communities they went to.
Decisions are made by politicians and bureaucrats, but they don't have all the information they need and their goals may not be in the best interest of the patients who are turned out into communities; endangering the patients and at times others. 
A closing date of 2018 doesn't allow much time for planning, does it?

Comment: Kudos for not turning this into a partisan political bun-fight, NA.  Harper, Martin and Cretien all had views different from Trudeau. 
But what are our laws if not a reflection of popular opinion? When they no longer reflect popular opinion they are challenged. For example, when three juries refused to convict Henry Morgentaler, it was a reflection of the fact that public opinion on the issue of abortion was changing. The law was thought to be unjust and it was changed. Similarly with laws related to homosexuality. People simply started to ignore them, so they were changed. Same with the issue of marijuana. Because something is written into law does not make it "just", even if the decision comes from the mouth of the Supreme Court itself.
People don't need to be told by lawyers what is right. There are many wacky legal decisions derived from the application of human rights legislation in a legal vacuum.  Rights must exist in balance with society's values, not in isolation from them.

Comment: Standing Rock protesters claim tribes weren’t consulted. US Federal court records show project leaders participated in 559 meetings with community leaders, local officials and organizations to fine-tune the route. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers held 389 meetings with 55 tribes.

October, upon arrival at an arranged meeting, Tribal Chairman David Archambault said the meeting had started early and was now over.  At a November meeting, the tribe took the pipeline off the agenda and refused to discuss it. Stonewalling continued for a year and a half.

Standing Rock Sioux met corps officials to discuss the route only after site work had begun; that work is now 77 percent complete at a cost of $3 billion. The Sioux squandered their opportunity to have input on the route.

Comment: You are right! Communism never failed in Norway, because Norway is not and never was a Communist country.
Norway has a thriving market based economy that has the fortunate backing of a 67% government owned share in Norwegian multinational oil and gas company Statoil ASA.

Statoil (then: Den Norske Stats Oljeselskap A/S) was founded in 1973 with taxpayer money. Because of the large capital investment required to establish the industry it was fully backed by the state (taxpayer) and did not create profits until the early 1980's, but once established it was privatised in 2001.
Although the State still holds a reduced amount of shares it has been selling them off and will continue to do so.

The highest ever percentage gained by the Communist Party of Norway was 11.9% in 1945 when it gained 11 out of 150 seats in parliament, they lost all 11 in the next election.	

PS: The current Government is Conservative.

Comment: Robin Brena has a plan, the legislature doesn't even have to hire a consultant...
https://www.adn.com/opinions/2016/10/01/alaska-needs-to-reclaim-its-fair-share-of-oil-revenue/

(1) The base rate for the major legacy fields and for harvesting behavior is insufficient.

(2) Credits are being politically gamed.

(3) Losses from the last method were carried forward.

(4) The definition of "new" oil is political sophistry.

(5) Progressivity is insufficient.

(6) Alaska is years behind in auditing the 55,000 lines of deductions currently being claimed.

---------------------------------------------

(1) Increase the base rate for the major legacy fields

(2) Eliminate credits

(3) Eliminate loss carryforwards.

(4) Eliminate the "new oil" definition

(5) Increase progressivity.

(6) Add the auditing and legal resources necessary to ensure revenue for the state and minimize gaming.

(7) Increase transparency so we know the financial performance of the producers operating in Alaska.

Comment: I don't follow your logic. 

It's highly common for restaurants to pool tips across the staff. If everyone provides great service, everyone gets great tips and vice versa. This obviously creates ambiguity for any staff individual to know the exact amount each customer tipped but, even if they did, it wouldn't change anything. The restaurant still has to strive for excellent service across all customers if they want to maximize their tips. 

This is the same principle for drivers. If you deliver late, forget a bag, or make the customer meet you outside, then you should expect little to no tip. I.e. Suboptimal service = suboptimal tip. 

What would a driver do different if they knew what each customer tipped?

Comment: In order to adequately define mental "illness", it is incumbent upon the label itself and upon those who proffer it to infer a baseline reference of normality, if such a thing is possible.  

Apart from the pejorative use of the terms mentally ill, crazy, insane and so forth to denote behavior that an observer finds distasteful, the notion of mental "illness" has been abused by many e.g. Russian gulags among other ideological prisons.  In particular, the medical establishment via every iteration of its DSM purports mental "illness" categories for nearly every human being alive to the point of ridiculousness.  Not long ago, homosexuality was a mental "illness" per DSM.

Is there a clear boundary between mental "illness" and a mere difference of opinion?  Is a reaction to social or personal injustice, perceived correctly or not, a mental "illness"?  The term should not be used lightly or flippantly by anyone, professional or otherwise and it certainly must not be used to excuse violence.

Comment: Well... The Constitution was ratified after a referendum on 6 December 1978, sanctioned by King Juan Carlos I on 27 December, and published in the Boletin Oficial del Estado on 29 December 1978. So the author does have a point in saying that when 90.4% of the Catalans voted in favour of the Constitution, they voted for its provisions on the indivisibility of Spain. Historically however, the issue is arguable in favour of Catalonia; because it was somehow an autonomous Principality until it was integrated in the Crown of Aragon by marriage in 1137. It then became part of Spain when the Crowns of Aragon and Castille fused together to form Spain. And finally with the end of the War of the Spanish Succession, all non-Castilian institutions, forms of public governance and even official language were abolished by force, as a result of the Bourbon Line's victory in that War in 1714.
So... historically, they do have a point to make!

Comment: Here is my take on oil and pipelines - like it or not the world uses a lot of oil and not just for gasoline but for plastics, chemicals etc.  While we have some replacements and are continuing to work on new ones we are going to be using oil for at least the next 50 years.  That means it needs to be transported and pipelines are the most efficient and safest option to do so.  Right now a substantial amount is moving by rail and truck which as LAc Magantic shows can be deadly.

Are there risks to pipelines, yes mostly from leaks, but that is still safer than exploding rail cars.  Personally I would prefer to build refineries in Alberta and then sell the value added goods instead of exporting the raw and importing the value add, which we do with too many of our resources but since that doesn't seem to be the plan, I would rather see oil moved by pipe than by truck or rail.

Comment: No one is circumventing anything as they are following one of the processes under our laws by which one may be recognized as a Convention Refugee. as defined in s. 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).

Arriving in Canada without legal status and claiming refugee status is one of the legal options under the IRPA which incorporates into domestic law one of our longstanding international obligations to refugees going back to 1951.  It is a major reason for the existence of the Refugee Protection Division and its predecessor tribunals.

BTW s.133 of the current IRPA provides an exemption for refugees for prosecution for illegal entry to Canada.  This exemption dates back to the UN 1951 Convention on Refugees contained in Article 31.

The oral hearing process before an independent administrative tribunal has been part of our law for over three decades and the reasons for it were set out in the 1985 SCOC decision in Singh v Canada [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177.

Comment: I understand what you're getting at.  The old torts of assault and battery separated the crime into the attempt or threat of using force against a person versus the actual physical force, the battery component.

But it seems pretty clear in Canadian law that determining the actus rea of sexual assault under S271 requires there to be touching, that it was sexual in nature, and that there was no consent.  

It's only under S272 that threatening a sexual assault with a weapon is sufficient to establish the actus rea of sexual assault with a weapon.

Which is why I do believe a verbal threat of sexual touching (without a weapon) would be prosecuted, if at all, as a common assault.

Comment: Two recent pastors of my acquaintance dealt with mass stipends in different ways. 

The first accepted the practice as something some parishioners were attached to, and generally nudged them to "mass cards" that directed funds to the support of training the clergy of his religious order. When the request was for him to say a mass for a particular person on a particular day, he accepted the stipend, but minimized the external acknowledgement of that stipend during the mass in question. And he refused to accept stipends for Sundays. The resulting external perception in the parish was that the stipend system has sort of disappear through attrition (a specifically desired result), while at the same not offending anyone. 

The second delighted in the system. He was eagerly accepted stipends for Sunday masses, announcing the names (1) in the bulletin, (2) in the announcements before mass, (3) during the prayers of the faithful, and (4) specific mention during the Eucharistic prayer. Ugh!!!

Comment: I have been to Deline in summer twice. The first was the end of a five week solo canoe trip from Behchoko on Great Slave Lake. The second was the start and end of an abortive canoe trip up the Johnnie Hoe River. Everything is expensive there. The government pays the transport costs for fuel. Fortunately the lake is full of fish. The water is clear. There is no pollution in it and the natives want to keep it that way. Not like Lake Athabasca downstream from the oil sands operation. Traffic on the road in town is mostly four wheelers (usually  carrying passengers) and pedestrians. Trucks are few. I watched hand games in the community center. A guy from one team passes a small object from hand to hand and the opposing team guesses which hand it is in. And the rest of the first team bangs on drums and yells at the top of their voices. The noise is deafening. The town is dry, at least during the tourist season. Surely a good place to end a canoe trip.

Comment: No, it was abandoned because most health statisticians and methodologists questioned everything from the selection of indicators quality of the data (including how data was simulated when absent for vast number of countries and indicators), the weighting/ranking method. The consensus conclusion among experts was it it really isn't valid to numerically rank health systems. 

But you can cling to your myth because it validates your pre-determined conclusion.

Even the Commonwealth Fund report can be critiqued with regards to ranking. The data is valid and valuable. However, it is based on a relatively small number of indicators (and changing the indicators can change the results). And weighting/ranking is always problematic (high subjectivity). The value is looking at the various indicators to assess performance. But the Commonwealth Fund wishes to draw attention to its work and objectives - and sensationalized ranking does that.

Comment: I appreciate you and Motley providing this information. I'm still getting fully up to speed on PERS history. But I do have one question: if the changes you mention have been effective in reducing the most generous pension payouts, while is PERS in crisis today? I do know that the recent reduction of the assumed rate of return on PERS investments had a big impact on what the taxpayers had to make up. And of course, the assumed rate of return is still way too high, so more pain to come for the taxpayers. Perhaps more focus should be put on the way PERS invests, investment costs, etc. Not that the rate of return will get back to 7 percent any time soon, but I do know, for example, that its hedge fund and private equity investments have underperformed for the better part of a decade. Simplifying its investments and shedding the losers all would save fees and possibly lead to a greater rate of return.

Comment: In that case, then, the rules of logic are greater than your god and constrain what s/he can do. S/he is therefore clearly not omnipotent.  (And anyway, who created logic and its rules in the first place?)  René Descartes recognised this problem and insisted that an omnipotent god must be allowed to create with “absolute freedom.”

Like it or not, that means that an omnipotent god must be able to create logical absurdities such as square circles, married bachelors, dead life and so forth.  If you insist on omnipotence (and/or any of the other assumed infinite attributes with which gods are commonly credited), you cannot also insist on logical coherence, and vice versa.  That’s one of the sticky central dilemmas of god-belief.  What’s more, it limits what can reasonably said of any such proposed deity.

Comment: You should do some checking on the history of the ACA before making comments like that. The bill that was passed is completely different than the bill sent to the Hill by the Obama Administration. The original legislation was a single payer system, and was DOA due to objections from the GOP side of the aisle. They demanded and received an almost verbatim copy of the plan touted by the Heritage Foundation, the authors of the Massachusetts bill that Romney was proclaiming such a success during the last election cycle. The passage of the bill was subject to so many revisions that the final copy was rushed. At signing, the fact that this was a first try at a plan for the nation was talked about; the tragedy of it is that like most committee derived plans, it adequately solved few problems. Dropping it entirely will be difficult, amending it may be the best option at this point, save instituting a single payer plan, which has been proven to work.
